question_details.title: Who will win the next UK Labour Party Leadership Election? (Wes Streeting)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2022-07-14 05:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11825). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

*Related Questons on Metaculus:*

* [Will the party led by X form the first government after the next UK election?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11780/party-leaders-form-government-uk-election/)
* [When will Keir Starmer cease to be Leader of the Labour Party?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7174/keir-starmer-labour-leadership-exit-date/)

----

The [Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) of the United Kingdom is a one of the two major parties in the UK's [two-party political system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_Kingdom).  Since April 2020, the leader of the Labour Party is [Keir Starmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keir_Starmer).

The House of Commons [states](https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN03938/SN03938.pdf) that a leadership election is held if there is a vacancy in that role (such as from a resignation or vote of no confidence), or if the Leader is challenged prior to the annual session of the Party conference.  The incumbent is not required to be nominated and is automatically on the ballot; other candidates must recieve nominations from at least 10% of elected [MP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(United_Kingdom))s (or at least 20% if the Leader is being challenged).  Candidates are elected by party members with an [instant-runoff system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant-runoff_voting).

In June 2022, [The Times](https://archive.ph/t5GyY) reported that Keir Starmer was preparing his colleagues for a new leadership election if he was called to step down (for instance, in response to the ["beergate" scanadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keir_Starmer#Partygate_and_Beergate_controversy)).  The Times named [Wes Streeting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Streeting) and [Lisa Nandy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Nandy) as likely candidates.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'Wes Streeting'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

The question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is the winner of the next UK Labour Party leadership election following the election on April 4, 2020.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed below; more options may be added in the future.
question_details.fine_print: If the Labour party ceases to exist, or if the next Labour party leader is chosen by a process other than a leadership election, this question will resolve as **Ambiguous**.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**SNP backs Swinney's 'clear' strategy for new independence referendum**
SNP members overwhelmingly endorsed leader John Swinney's 'clear and unambiguous' strategy for a second independence referendum, affirming that winning a majority of seats—65 or more—in the next Holyrood election (May 2026) is the only uncontested path to securing a new vote on Scotland's future. The motion, passed during the party’s annual conference in Aberdeen, rejected a rebel amendment proposing a 'de facto' referendum model—where a pro-independence majority in the popular vote would automatically trigger independence negotiations—despite its prior advocacy by former leader Nicola Sturgeon, who later called it a 'mistake.' Swinney emphasized the party is 'within touching distance' of the 65-seat threshold, urging a clear message to voters. Depute leader Keith Brown reinforced the need for a 'clear question and clear answer.' The shift reflects renewed confidence after the SNP’s 2024 general election collapse, where it lost 38 of 48 Westminster seats amid criticism of a muddled strategy. Now leading in polls ahead of Scottish Labour and Reform UK, the party is targeting 'soft yes' supporters who have drifted away. However, the proportional representation system makes a majority difficult—SNP has only achieved it once, in 2011 under Alex Salmond. Keir Starmer has repeatedly stated he will not grant Holyrood the power to hold a second referendum.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 11, 2025 04:22 PM
Source:[The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2025/oct/11/snp-backs-swinneys-clear-strategy-for-new-independence-referendum)

**Bridget Phillipson v Lucy Powell - behind the battle for Labour's number two**
The race for Labour's deputy leadership between Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell is a pivotal moment for the party, which is navigating internal discontent following a disappointing performance in the polls just 18 months after a major election victory. Neither candidate is from the far left or the New Labour faction, and both are relatively well-known within the party, though less so than outgoing deputy Angela Rayner, who resigned after breaching the ministerial code by failing to pay enough tax on her £800,000 flat. The deputy leader role lacks a formal job description but includes participation in the National Executive Committee, the political cabinet (a senior party meeting without civil servants), and the weekly parliamentary meeting. The role is not automatically the deputy prime minister—David Lammy holds that position. One source describes the deputy as the 'campaigner in chief,' highlighting its strategic importance ahead of May's elections. Powell, recently sacked from the cabinet without a clear explanation, argues for open debate and a 'course correction' in government, criticizing the perceived clique around Prime Minister Keir Starmer. Her backers claim the party needs a 'yin to the yang' of No 10 to balance power. Phillipson’s team warns that an outspoken deputy could destabilize the government, arguing instead for a quiet, inside advocate who pushes members' interests—especially on poverty—without becoming a lightning rod for dissent. Phillipson promises to increase member involvement by soliciting views every three months via app or website, holding direct online meetings with ministers, and restricting National Policy Forum (NPF) submissions to official party-linked organizations. Powell has stronger backing from constituency parties and affiliated groups like the Society of Labour Lawyers, while Phillipson has more MPs and union support. Despite Powell being the favorite according to most Labour sources and limited polling, the outcome remains uncertain. The contest reflects broader member frustration with Starmer’s leadership and decisions. A Powell win could be seen as a rebuke to Starmer, potentially reinforcing the narrative of his 'non-Midas touch.' The decision will ultimately reflect whether Labour members want a visible, external voice or a discreet, internal advocate. The race has already seen mutual criticism, with Phillipson’s allies accusing Powell of avoiding TV hustings and Powell dismissing claims of divisiveness as 'ridiculous.' Both have campaigned widely across 20+ events. The role of deputy leader has historically varied—from loyal enabler to pressure valve to internal opposition—shaping the dynamics of leadership. The outcome may serve as a referendum on Starmer’s leadership style and the party’s direction.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 11, 2025 12:51 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://ca.news.yahoo.com/bridget-phillipson-v-lucy-powell-125120877.html)

**'Voters will go to Reform': Labour anger as Starmer pushes on with digital ID**
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer faces growing internal and public backlash over his government's digital ID policy, which was announced before Labour's conference but received minimal attention during the event. Polling shows a sharp decline in public support, with over 2.8 million people signing a petition opposing the plan. Labour MPs are expressing anger, citing an influx of angry constituent emails and protests outside the conference. Critics argue the government failed to effectively communicate the policy’s purpose—initially framed as a tool to address irregular migration—but now repositioned as a means to simplify access to public services. Concerns have intensified over the potential inclusion of 13-year-olds in the rollout, with critics calling it 'sinister' and 'Orwellian'. Downing Street acknowledges the need for a renewed communications strategy, with Starmer calling for a 'national debate' on the issue. Former Labour strategist John McTernan urged a shift from the outdated 'grid' model of policy announcements to continuous campaigning, emphasizing the need to repeatedly tell the story of how digital ID benefits citizens. Despite the backlash, the government plans to introduce fresh planning reforms next week to stimulate economic growth ahead of a challenging Budget, with hopes the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) will boost growth forecasts. However, business leaders remain wary of further taxation, and the government faces scrutiny over the collapsed China spying case, with MPs demanding answers and accusing Starmer of being too accommodating toward China. Additionally, Labour MPs are expected to push for updates on SEND reforms, with fears of a potential rebellion similar to the failed welfare reform revolt earlier in the year. Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith criticized the government’s messaging, calling digital ID part of a series of ineffective anti-Reform policies, including 'one-in, one-out' and 'smash the gangs'. Labour MP Steve Yemm described the government’s challenges as comparable to rebuilding Britain after war, underscoring the scale of the task ahead.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 11, 2025 05:00 AM
Source:[inews.co.uk](https://inews.co.uk/news/politics/labour-anger-starmer-pushes-digital-id-3972503)

**SNP rebel plan for 'de facto' independence vote won't work, says Swinney**
John Swinney, First Minister of Scotland and leader of the SNP, has rejected a proposal by SNP rebels to use the 2026 Scottish Parliament election as a 'de facto' independence referendum, arguing that such a strategy would not secure international or UK government recognition. The rebels' plan, backed by nine SNP branches, calls for independence-supporting parties—including Alba and the Greens—to initiate divorce negotiations with the UK if they collectively win a majority of the popular vote, bypassing a formal referendum. Swinney insists that only a clear, constitutionally valid referendum can deliver a legitimate mandate for independence, citing the 2014 precedent and the need for domestic and international legitimacy. He dismissed Nicola Sturgeon’s 2022 proposal to use a general election as a de facto referendum, stating it would not work. Swinney also predicted that if the SNP wins a majority in 2026, Keir Starmer would be forced to resign, and his successor would be more likely to allow a new referendum. Meanwhile, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar criticized the SNP for internal divisions over independence while public services, particularly the NHS, face crisis levels, warning that the NHS 'may not survive another five years of SNP incompetence.' Swinney acknowledged the lack of a 'shortcut' to reducing record NHS waiting lists, referencing a Royal College of Emergency Medicine report linking over 800 deaths in Scotland to A&E delays. He also addressed tensions with hospital doctors, as the British Medical Association (BMA) plans a pay strike ballot, despite the Scottish Health Secretary offering 4.25% for 2025–26 and 3.75% for 2026–27, which nurses accepted. The debate over the independence strategy will be decided during the SNP conference in Aberdeen.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 10, 2025 08:52 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/snp-rebel-plan-facto-independence-205218973.html)

**Keir Starmer’s Woes and Media Magnification**
Sir Keir Starmer, the UK's Prime Minister since Labour's decisive victory in July 2024, faces mounting criticism and declining public appeal, according to a critical article from Dissident Voice published on October 9, 2025. Despite initial momentum, Starmer is portrayed as experiencing a 'precipitous decline,' with unnamed 'insiders' and party figures criticizing his leadership, judgment, communication skills, and perceived lack of executive presence. The BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg reported speaking to 30 unnamed government and party officials, all expressing concerns about Starmer’s leadership style and policy decisions. Media magnification is cited as a key factor in eroding his popularity, with outlets amplifying internal dissent and speculation about a leadership challenge. Potential challengers include Andy Burnham, the Mayor of Greater Manchester, and Shabana Mahmood, the new Home Secretary, though none have formally declared. The article also highlights the rising threat of Nigel Farage’s Reform UK, which gained 677 councillors in May 2025 and was projected by YouGov on September 26, 2025, to win 311 seats in a hypothetical election—surpassing Labour’s 21% polling in The Guardian’s October 2025 tracker. The article notes the UK’s First Past the Post system may suppress such challengers, but Reform UK’s surge reflects broader European trends of nationalist discontent over crime and immigration. At Labour’s Liverpool conference, Starmer delivered a 'full-throated defence of progressive values,' with some observers noting an emotional connection in his speech. Defenders include Fraser Nelson of The Spectator, who counters Farage’s claims with data from the Crime Survey for England and Wales showing a four-fifths drop in crime since 1995. However, Starmer is criticized for failing to effectively counter the fear-driven narrative propagated by Reform UK, while the Conservatives are seen as waiting for Labour’s downfall.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 09, 2025 02:10 PM
Source:[Dissident Voice](https://dissidentvoice.org/2025/10/keir-starmers-woes-and-media-magnification/)

**Sir Keir Starmer expected to blame Nigel Farage for tax rises - Birmingham Live**
Sir Keir Starmer, the UK Prime Minister, is expected to blame Reform UK leader Nigel Farage for upcoming tax rises, accusing him of 'easy sloganeering' during the 2016 Brexit referendum campaign. The Labour government is citing official data from The Times suggesting the UK economy would be approximately £120 billion larger by 2035 if not for Brexit. This comes amid sluggish economic growth, with UK GDP increasing by only 0.3% in Quarter 2 (April to June) 2025, following a 0.7% rise in Quarter 1 (January to March) 2025, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Starmer directly attacked Farage at the Labour Party conference, claiming he 'doesn't like Britain' and 'doesn't believe in Britain,' and questioned whether Farage has ever said anything positive about the country's future. He accused Farage and others on both the right and left of prioritizing decline for political gain, calling them 'snake oil merchants' who rely on grievance and victimhood narratives. In response, Farage posted a video on X (formerly Twitter), asserting that Starmer is 'not fit to be Prime Minister' and accusing Labour of labelling critics of immigration policies as racist. Farage claimed Reform UK is ahead in the polls and that Labour is in 'blind panic,' arguing that their policies are inconsistent and that he and his party represent sensible, grown-up governance. The exchange reflects a heightened political rivalry ahead of the next general election.

Publish date: October 11, 2025 08:37 AM
Source:[Birmingham Mail](https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/uk-news/sir-keir-starmer-expected-blame-32657146)

The article outlines several routes: winning a by‑election after a Labour MP resigns, acting as a kingmaker by endorsing a challenger, or waiting until the next general election to stand as an MP. Each route has procedural hurdles and requires alignment of circumstances. summary:
Across all expert perspectives—including political consulting, polling analysis, UK parliamentary affairs, political science, sociology, and British studies—there is a strong consensus that Wes Streeting has a low probability of winning the next UK Labour Party leadership election. The majority of forecasts cluster around probabilities of 4% to 8% for a Streeting victory, with the most common figure being 5% to 7%.

Recurring reasons for the low probability include:
- No imminent leadership contest: Keir Starmer remains Labour leader, and while his popularity is declining, there is no sign of an imminent resignation or challenge, and Labour’s rules make it difficult to trigger a contest.
- Stronger rivals: Andy Burnham (if he returns to Parliament), Shabana Mahmood, and Ed Miliband are consistently mentioned as front-runners, commanding higher member favorability, broader elite or grassroots support, and deeper factional or network backing.
- Streeting’s limited base: Polling (e.g., LabourList net favorability +9 for Streeting, versus +74 for Miliband) and analysis indicate Streeting lacks a strong grassroots, union, or Parliamentary factional base and does not lead in any major party demographic.
- Leadership election mechanics: The party’s electoral system (high MP nomination threshold, need for cross-factional appeal, instant-runoff voting) favors more prominent, broadly appealing, or well-networked candidates.

Most experts allow for a very narrow pathway in which Streeting could win, typically involving a highly fragmented contest where all major rivals falter or fail to unify, allowing him to emerge as a compromise candidate. However, this is deemed highly unlikely under current conditions and historical base rates.

The median probability estimated by the experts is around 6-7%. In summary, while Wes Streeting is mentioned as a potential candidate, his prospects are considered slim given the field of likely contenders, current party sentiment, and structural party dynamics.
